profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-04-06 15:24:17 -0400.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment and is limited to the Archives' Washington, D.C., Research Center. Microfilmed materials must be consulted on microfilm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: REEL 3481: Six letters from Bradley Walker Tomlin, 1948-1952, and 15 from Mark Rothko, 1945-1950; catalogs with introductions by Newman, and other writings; catalogs, announcements and clippings on Newman, 1943-1971; a photograph of Newman at the opening of "The Intrasubjectives" at Kootz Gallery, 1949; and a photograph of Peggy Guggenheim with Polish artist Teresa Zarnower, ca. 1950.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: UNMICROFILMED: Thirty letters from Clyfford Still, 1946-1956, addressed to Barnett and Annalee Newman. The letters were written during the period Still was teaching at the California School of Fine Art in San Francisco. He writes of his alienation from the New York and California art world, Clement Greenberg, the Bauhaus aesthetic, and his CSFA colleagues, including Ad Reinhardt, and his rift with Mark Rothko.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: 35mm microfilm reel 3481 available at Archives of American Art offices and through interlibrary loan.

altformavail.head: Reproduction Note
altformavail.p: Rothko, Still and Tomlin letters: are photocopies.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals
originalsloc.p: Rothko, Still, and Tomlin letters: Originals retained by Mrs. Barnett Newman.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Barnett Newman (1905-1970) was a painter and writer in New York.
